conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the wire ab in the magnetic field.
The wire is suspended by two spring scales, and the magnetic force on the wire will affect the readings of the spring scales.
The magnetic force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by F = I L B sin θ.
I is the current, L is the length of the wire, B is the magnetic field strength, and θ is the angle between the current and the magnetic field.
Since θ = 90°, the magnetic force is F = I L B.
When the current is I, the magnetic force on the wire is F = I L B.
The force is vertical and acts downward if the current is from a to b or upward if the current is from b to a.
The spring scales read the effective weight of the wire minus the magnetic force if the force is downward, or the effective weight plus the magnetic force if the force is upward.
Since the wire is in equilibrium, the sum of the forces on the wire must be zero.
The reading of each spring scale is F_scale = (W - F) / 2.
Given that the reading of one of the spring scales is F1, F1 = (W - I L B) / 2.
When the current is 2I, the magnetic force on the wire is F = 2I L B.
The reading of the spring scales will now be F_scale = (W - 2I L B) / 2.
Given that the reading of one of the spring scales is F2, F2 = (W - 2I L B) / 2.
Set up the equations F1 = (W - I L B) / 2 and F2 = (W - 2I L B) / 2.
Subtract the first equation from the second: F2 - F1 = -(I L B) / 2.
Simplify to find B: I L B = 2(F1 - F2).
The magnitude of the magnetic induction B is B = 2(F1 - F2) / (I L).
The final answer is B = 2(F1 - F2) / (I L).
